properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant winter storm expected Monday into Wednesday. A low pressure system is expected to track just east of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario on Monday bringing rain, snow and strong winds throughout Southern Ontario. This low pressure system is expected to remain over Southern Ontario until Wednesday. Precipitation is expected to begin Monday morning as rain or snow and change to snow Monday afternoon. Snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are possible by Tuesday morning. Additional snowfall amounts near 25 cm are a possibility Tuesday through Wednesday morning, particularly in areas near Georgian Bay and Lake Huron. Total snowfall amounts are fairly uncertain at this time, however. Strong northwesterly winds gusting near 70 km/h are also possible Monday night and Tuesday, particularly near Georgian Bay. Difficult travel conditions are expected as snow covered and icy roads are possible, particularly Monday evening into Tuesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-30T12:20:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-29T20:21:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3827511753.2020
Area: Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant winter storm expected Monday into Wednesday. A low pressure system is expected to track just east of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario on Monday bringing rain, snow and strong winds throughout Southern Ontario. This low pressure system is expected to remain over Southern Ontario until Wednesday. Precipitation is expected to begin Monday morning as rain or snow and change to snow Monday afternoon. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible by Tuesday morning. Snow will continue Tuesday into Wednesday morning, with additional snowfall amounts near 10 cm possible. Total snowfall amounts are fairly uncertain at this time, however. Difficult travel conditions are expected as snow covered and icy roads are possible, particularly Monday night into Tuesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and mild temperatures for the beginning of the week. Rainfall amounts of 40 to 50 millimetres are expected beginning Monday afternoon and continuing into Tuesday morning. The onset of rain will coincide with rising temperatures, which may melt part of the snow cover. Heavy rain may cause ponding on roads. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant storm to come. A total of 15 to 30 centimetres of snow is expected from Tuesday morning to Wednesday morning. The combination of this particularly heavy snow and moderate winds could cause broken tree limbs. Travel conditions could also be difficult. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, snow and strong winds early next week. An intense low pressure system will affect much of the province from Monday afternoon through Wednesday. Rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 millimetres are expected over Southern and Central Quebec. This rain will be accompanied by strong winds with well above normal temperatures. The further east you go, the more rain is expected. The Gaspé Peninsula and the North Shore could see 50 to 80 millimetres of rain between Tuesday and Wednesday. There too, strong northeast winds will combine with the poor weather conditions and could cause coastal flooding in some areas. Areas further north will receive about 10 centimetres of snow, except the Manicouagan region, which could receive about 20. Subsequent weather statements will provide more information as the low pressure system's track becomes more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-30T02:02:46-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, freezing rain and rain from Monday evening into Wednesday. A total of 10 to 15 centimetres of snow is expected beginning Monday evening. Early Wednesday morning, the snow may change to freezing rain for a more or less extended period. Temperatures will then rise above the freezing mark and precipitation will change over to rain. Travel conditions could be difficult. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potentially damaging winds today and Monday for the B.C. south coast. Southeast 50 to 80 km/h winds will develop this morning and will sharply veer to northwest 50 to 70 km/h tonight or early Monday morning as a strong cold front blasts through southwest B.C. Exposed coastal sections of northern Vancouver Island southeast winds near 80 km/h have developed this morning. Winds will shift to northwest 50 to 70 km/h in the evening. For Metro Vancouver, Southern Gulf Islands, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove and communities in the mouth of Howe Sound, including Bowen Island, the south to southeast winds up to 60 km/h will peak overnight and early Monday morning. The wind will veer sharply to the northwest 40 to 60 km/h Monday morning before easing near noon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-30T10:25:09-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, strong winds and storm surge conditions early in the week. The Gaspé Peninsula and the North Shore will receive 50 to 80 millimetres of rain between Monday night and Wednesday. Rainfall amounts could even reach 100 millimetres over some localities of the tip of the Gaspé Peninsula and the Lower North Shore. Strong east winds combined will combine with the poor weather conditions and could cause breaking sea conditions in some areas. The heavy rain may cause flash floods and ponding on roads. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-30T13:04:20-00:00

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A robust frontal system is passing through the north coast regions of BC. Wet snow, heavy at times, will continue for the Stewart region. 47 cm has already fallen, and another 5 cm is forecast to fall. As the frontal system moves further inland, temperatures are expected to rise to above freezing in the next few hours. At this point the heavy, wet snow will turn to rain. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-30T01:19:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-29T18:52:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3731690542.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An approaching Pacific frontal system will spread strong winds to the West Vancouver Island region tonight. Southeast winds ahead of the front will rise to 80 km/h gusting to 100 this evening and the winds will sharply veer to northwest 50 to 70 km/h overnight. The winds are expected to ease Monday morning as the front moves inland. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-30T04:49:50-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant winter storm expected Monday into Wednesday. A low pressure system is expected to track just east of Lake Erie and Lake Ontario on Monday bringing rain, snow and strong winds throughout Southern Ontario. This low pressure system is expected to remain over Southern Ontario until Wednesday. Precipitation is expected to begin Monday morning mainly as rain; however, rain may be mixed with snow at times. Rain is then expected to change to snow Monday afternoon or evening with snow continuing into Wednesday. Snowfall amounts near 5 to 10 cm are possible by Tuesday morning, with locally 15 cm possible especially near Lake Huron. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible on Tuesday; however, these snowfall amounts remain fairly uncertain. Strong northwesterly winds gusting near 70 km/h are also possible Monday night and Tuesday near Lake Huron. Difficult travel conditions are expected as snow covered and icy roads are possible, particularly Monday night into Tuesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-30T12:26:29-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and persistent freezing rain expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Freezing rain duration: 8 to 12 hours. Locations: Labrador. Time span: Monday evening until later this week. Remarks: Snow will begin Monday evening over western Labrador and spread to the Labrador coast on Tuesday. In the north, the precipitation is expected to remain as mainly snow. In the southeast, it is expected to transition to mainly rain. Elsewhere, the snow is expected to change over to an extended period of freezing rain. The heaviest snowfall rates are expected during the day on Tuesday and the heaviest freezing rainfall rates are expected overnight Tuesday and into Wednesday morning. This wintry mix of snow, freezing rain and rain is expected to persist over much of Labrador into later this week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-30T11:44:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-29T19:45:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3519384877.2020

properties.Summary:
Description: Location: western and northern Nova Scotia. Time span: Monday night through Wednesday afternoon. Rainfall amount: 50 to 80 mm likely, with higher amounts possible. Remarks: An intense low pressure system is forecast to move into New England on Monday. Rain ahead of this system will move into the region Monday night and will become heavy at times on Tuesday. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 80 mm are likely with locally higher amounts possible. Additionally, gusty southeast winds are expected on Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A pacific frontal system will spread strong winds to most South Coastal regions tonight including Greater Victoria. As the front approaches overnight, winds near Haro Strait will rise to southeast 50 to 70 km/h. In the wake of the front, 50 to 70 km/h westerly winds are forecast for neighbourhoods near Juan de Fuca Strait early Monday morning. Winds will abate Monday afternoon. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:

Potential Rainfall amount: 50 to 100 mm with higher amounts possible in areas of heaviest rain. Remarks: An intense low pressure system is expected to move into New England on Monday. Rain ahead of this system will move into western New Brunswick Monday afternoon and spread northeastward Monday night and will become heavy at times. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 100 mm are likely with locally higher amounts possible. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong Pacific frontal system will slowly move east through Haida Gwaii. Ahead of the front, strong southeasterly winds of 90 km/h will continue over exposed coastal sections of the North and Central Coast and Haida Gwaii. The winds will ease this evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. An approaching Pacific frontal system will spread strong winds to most South Coastal regions tonight. Southeasterly winds ahead of the front will rise to 70 km/h gusting to 90 over the exposed coastal sections of Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, as well as the Central and northern sections of East Vancouver Island this evening. The winds are expected to veer to northwest 40 to 60 km/h Monday morning in the wake of the front. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
